person.author: Sérapion
person.note: See note on other entry for Sérapion.

author.note: Bishop of Iconium connected with the Cappadocian Fathers. Syriac translations of works attributed to him include an encomium on Basil, and a hagiographic work about Athanasius of Alexandria.

bibl.title: The Gorgias Encyclopedic Dictionary of the Syriac Heritage
Gewargis I

person.note: Should we assume this is pseudonymous, like the works about Basil attributed to Amphilochius?
Bishop of Constantinople (406-425) and author of a homily on the Virgin Mary extant in Syriac

bibl.title: A Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Christianity

author.note: Chabot (Journal asiatique, 1895, pp. 111, 141) identifies this author as a companion of Catholicos Denḥa I , possibly his secretary, and infers his name as "ܝܘܚܢܢ" ("Jean") on the basis of a kind of anagram in his text.
A disciple of Dioscorus of Alexandria , according to Nau (Journal asiatique, 1903, pp. 21-106).
The author of a hagiographic work about the saint Sāhdā Marī d-Bēth-Sāhdē.

author.persName: Author of the 'Book of the Ḥimyarites'

person.note: According to http://contentdm.lib.byu.edu/cdm/ref/collection/CUA/id/45292 on page lxvii the author is MAYBE Bishop Sergius (Georgios) of Rusafa, need new URI and a modifier on attribution of author to uncertain. Also has been attributed to Simeon of Beth Arsham (see GEDSH, 197).

person.author: Amphiloque d’Iconium
person.note: Other works of Amphiloque are of questionable authenticity. I haven't been able to find out more about this one, so for now, I've put "attributed".

author.note: Theologian and author of numerous Greek works, of which The Monks of Sinai survives in a Syriac version.

person.author: Kamis bar Qardahé
person.note: Khamis is attributed (see, e.g., Wright, Cambridge, 1:162), but what @type should we put on the author?

author.note: A monk to whom is attributed a work about the Virgin Mary

person.author: Jacques de Serugh
person.note: Is this an OK way to mark two possible but uncertain authors /person/42 and the monk Phocas of Gagim also know as Malke etc. See: https://archive.org/stream/MinganaCatalogueOfTheMinganaCollection.I/Mingana_Catalogue%20of%20the%20Mingana%20Collection.I#page/n467/mode/2up "Jacob" is attributed in Ms. Borg. sir. 128 f. 78v. (http://digi.vatlib.it/view/MSS_Borg.sir.128/0160)

bibl.title: Catalogue of the Mingana Collection of Manuscripts

author.persName: GRYGWRY of Reshʿaina, disciple of Sophronios
Gregorios from Reshʿaina, a disciple of Sophronios, the bishop of Jerusalem
author.note: Author of a work about his contemporary Maximus the Confessor (d. 662), and a bishop under Sophronios of Jerusalem (r. 634-638). The manuscript witness (BM Add. 7192, ff. 72b-78b) gives his name as both Gewargis and Gregorios, one of which is likely a scribal error.

Brock tentatively suggests the identification of this George with the author of an apparently monothelete Chalcedonian florilegium contained in BM Add. 14535 ff. 1-20. He considers it unlikely that this author was late enough to be identified with the George present at the Sixth Council (680/681).
author.death: after the death of Maximus the Confessor (662)

bibl.title: An Early Syriac Life of Maximus the Confessor
Analecta Bollandiana

person.note: Do we need URIs for either the haṣya George or the George at the sixth council? See notes above. Also, how can we label his confession as Chalcedonian monothelete?

author.note: Pseudonymous 5th century (or later) Armenian author of the life of Gregory the Illuminator

bibl.title: A Comprehensive Bibliography on Syriac Christianity

person.note:
I think this record is ready now.
Agathange/Agathangelos was the author -- the name of the abbreviator is not given so far as I can tell. Nor is Agathange's name given in Syriac at the beginning or end of the work.
This is an interesting challenge, besides pseudo we need continuator and abbreviator? Can you get: van Esbroeck, M. 1977.“Le résumé syriaque de l'Agathange.” AB 95: 291–358 (esp. 292). Pg. 292 says "Rappelons brièvement que diverse détails de cette forme de l'Agathange rendent son éclosion probable entre les années 604 à 610" Should we just use "editor" element with @type="abbreviator"?
Scriptural commentator and author of a hagiographical work on the Virgin Mary

author.note: Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia; successor and biographer of Basil of Caesarea
author.state: after the rule of Basil (late 4th century)

bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

person.author: Eusèbe de Césarée (Hist. eccl.)
person.note: what do with this?

persName.roleName: ܕܗܘ݂ܐ ܬܠܡܝܕܗ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܡܪܝ ܐܦܝܦܢ ܐܦܝܣܩܘܦܐ ܕܩܘܦܪܘܣ
who was a disciple of the holy Mar Epiphanius, bishop of Cyprus

person.note: A disciple of Epiphanius of Salamis.

bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

author.persName: Pantaleon, a priest from the monastery of the Byzantines

person.note: Wright, in his Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum, mistakenly calls him Pantaleon "of Byzantium," whereas his Syriac description should actually be translated "from the monastery of the Byzantines."

bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

revisionDesc.change: Record Zanetti's author note "HE" (=Historia ecclesiastica).

author.note: Biographer of Gregory of Nazianzus

bibl.title: Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838

revisionDesc.change: Record Zanetti's author note "Lettre à Cyriaque"

person.author: Isaïe
person.note: Given the identity issues with Isaiah of Scetis, would be safest to just mark "attribution." (Zanetti seems to intend the Isaiah who authored the Asceticon, i.e., "Isaiah of Scetis," but his citation of Drauget's edition does not exactly match the CSCO volume mentioned in GEDSH (211-212) (see http://www.peeters-leuven.be/boekoverz.asp?nr=1171).)

author.note: A bishop martyred in 312, whose name was pseudonymously attached to an apocalyptic work.

person.note: Is @type="pseudo" an OK way to handle "Pseudo-Méthode d’Olympe"?

author.note: Supposed author of a hagiographical work about his contemporary, Eulogius.

bibl.title: Die Handschriften-Verzeichnisse der Königlichen Bibliothek zu Berlin

person.bibl: ms Berlin, Königliche Bibliothek, syr. 74 (Sachau 9), f. 78

person.author: Shemkha de Beth-Saydaya
person.note: Is Zanetti's "Shemkha" really a spelling we should keep? E.g., Scher spells it "Schemcha"

person.author: Sérapion
person.note:
Checking with J-N about this:
There are 2 texts (http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/work/1728 and http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/work/1031) about Mark the Hermit of Tarmaqa, whom I take to be this Marqos (http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/1356, fl. 4th cent.). These stories are said to be narrated by an Abba Serapion the monk while he was in the Egyptian desert/interior of Scetis. I can’t seem to find out more information about this Serapion. Is he the same as http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2065 and/or http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2067? (These two look to me like they are probably the same, whereas the Serapion here http://wwwb.library.vanderbilt.edu/exist/apps/srophe/person/2066 from a group of martyrs looks different.)

author.note: A 7th-cent. historian whose work is quoted in the Chronicle of Siirt

person.note: since this is a text about the martyrs, does this refer to the same "Bar Sahde" mentioned in GEDSH, or is it a name related to the martyrdoms?

person.author: Isaac d’Antioche
person.note: At most this should be an "attribution." But Wright's catalogue doesn't even say Isaac for this work. So remove author altogether?

person.author: Méthode d’Olympe
person.note: Is @type="pseudo" an OK way to handle "Pseudo-Méthode d’Olympe"?

author.note: Iyob Metkarkana is attested from at least one work attributed to him: Rabban Sargis (text)

person.note: check transliteration and abstract

author.note: Chaldean metropolitan of ʿAqra and author of a history of the Oriental Chaldean Church

editor.note: ʿAbd al-Aḥad of Baʿshiqa is attested as the translator of at least one text: Samuel of Qartmin (text)

person.note: editor type, author note, and GEDSH transliteration

author.note: Cyril of Scythopolis is attested as the author of at least one work that was translated into Syriac: Euthymius (text).

revisionDesc.change: Record Zanetti's author note "HMP" ( = History of the Martyrs in Palestine)

person.author: Côme le Diacre
person.note: Wright, 3:1124 says this is written by Cosmas. Not sure why Zanetti had question mark. Should we mark @type="attributed" or @type="disputed"?

author.note: A nun pseudonymously credited with a Life of Febronia. The author of this work claims to have been a fellow nun with Febronia and to have later received charge of the convent.

person.note: Is this an OK way to describe the purported author of a pseudonymous work? See https://books.google.de/books?id=VwvByTL55jIC pg. 150 for more info.

bibl.title: Holy women of the Syrian Orient

person.author: Jean d’Éphèse

person.note: Wright, 2:819 "probably that ascribed to Ephrem"

author.ref: http://syriaca.org/person/1513 http://syriaca.org/person/1405 http://syriaca.org/person/1323 http://syriaca.org/person/1322 http://syriaca.org/person/1320 http://syriaca.org/person/1308 http://syriaca.org/person/2155 http://syriaca.org/person/1826 http://syriaca.org/person/1825 http://syriaca.org/person/1824 http://syriaca.org/person/1823 http://syriaca.org/person/1821 http://syriaca.org/person/1820 http://syriaca.org/person/1818 http://syriaca.org/person/1817 http://syriaca.org/person/1816 http://syriaca.org/person/1815 http://syriaca.org/person/1814 http://syriaca.org/person/1813 http://syriaca.org/person/1811 http://syriaca.org/person/1810 http://syriaca.org/person/1808 http://syriaca.org/person/1807 http://syriaca.org/person/1806 http://syriaca.org/person/1805 http://syriaca.org/person/1804 http://syriaca.org/person/1803 http://syriaca.org/person/1802 http://syriaca.org/person/1801 http://syriaca.org/person/488 http://syriaca.org/person/411

person.author: Jean
person.note: Can't figure out where Zanetti got the authorship info from. Univ. of Chicago catalog does not have that info. This article (http://documents.irevues.inist.fr/bitstream/handle/2042/35065/po1975_159.pdf?sequence=1) discusses a different work of a "bishop John" contained in the same ms.

editor.note: A notary, apparently of the city of Edessa, who, along with Anatolus, is attested as the recorder of a hagiographic work about Sharbēl
A notary, apparently of the city of Edessa, who, along with Marinus, is attested as the recorder of a hagiographic work about Sharbēl

person.note: Is editor @type="scribe" OK for "Marin et Anatole, excepteurs"? Actually, Marinus and Anatolius are mentioned as "notaries" who wrote down the account for Edessa's archive (https://archive.org/stream/ancientsyriacdo00wriggoog#page/n82/mode/2up). So should they be recorded as scribes?

bibl.title: Ancient Syriac documents relative to earliest establishment of Christianity in Edessa and the neighbouring countries, from the year after our Lord's Ascension to the beginning of the fourth century
Ancient Syriac documents relative to earliest establishment of Christianity in Edessa and the neighbouring countries, from the year after our Lord's Ascension to the beginning of the fourth century

editor.note: A notary, apparently of the city of Edessa, who along with Patrophilus is attested as the recorder of a hagiographic work about the bishop Barsamyā
A notary, apparently of the city of Edessa, who along with Zenophilus is attested as the recorder of a hagiographic work about the bishop Barsamyā

person.note: What editor @type should we use for these "notaries" (https://archive.org/stream/ancientsyriacdo00wriggoog#page/n93/mode/1up)? Also, the names seem a bit suspicious to me.

bibl.title: Ancient Syriac documents relative to earliest establishment of Christianity in Edessa and the neighbouring countries, from the year after our Lord's Ascension to the beginning of the fourth century
Ancient Syriac documents relative to earliest establishment of Christianity in Edessa and the neighbouring countries, from the year after our Lord's Ascension to the beginning of the fourth century

author.note: A disciple of Aaron of Serugh
Honored as a doctor of the Church of the East, Ishai was a disciple of Aba I and held the position of Interpreter of the school of Selucia-Ctesiphon. He also authored a treatise on the Holy Martyrs.

bibl.title: Histoire de Mar-Jabalaha: de trois autres patriarches, d'un prêtre et de deux laïques, Nestoriens
Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Museum Acquired since the Year 1838
La Version syriaque de l’Histoire de Jean le Petit

person.note:
Which editor @type should we use?
Nau says that Zachariah "prononcé" the original Coptic or Arabic version (https://archive.org/stream/revuedelorientch171912pari#page/348/mode/2up), whereas Wright takes the note at the beginning of the text to mean Zachariah was the translator (3:1115). However, the Syriac could mean "explain," etc. Include an abstract once we've decided how to handle this.

person.author: Isaac d’Antioche
person.note: Probably safer to use "attributed"

person.floruit: soemtime after Rabban Bar ʿEdta's death, during the reign of a metropolitan named ʿAbdishoʿ
person.note: Author of a metrical life of Rabban Bar ʿEdta, possibly during the time of ʿAbdishoʿ bar Bahrīz
